comment: A Moore collection is a set. That is, if we define a "Moore class-predicate" by ` ( Moore A <-> A. x e. ~P A ( U. A i^i |^| x ) e. A ) ` , then any class satisfying that predicate is actually a set. Therefore, the definition ~ df-bj-moore is sufficient. Note that the closed sets of a topology form a Moore collection, so this remark also applies to topologies and many other families of sets (namely, as soon as the whole set is required to be a closed set, as can be seen from the proof, which relies crucially on ~ uniexr ). Note: if, in the above predicate, we substitute ` ~P X ` for ` A ` , then the last ` e. ~P X ` could be weakened to ` C_ X ` , and then the predicate would be obviously satisfied since ` U. ~P X = X ` ( ~ unipw ) , making ` ~P X ` a Moore collection in this weaker sense, even if ` X ` is a proper class, but the addition of this single case does not add anything interesting. Instead, we have ~ bj-discrmoore . (Contributed by BJ, 8-Dec-2021.)
